claim: veganism kills more animals through crop harvesting.
fact: animal agriculture requires vastly more crops to feed livestock than would be needed to feed humans directly. a vegan diet actually requires less land and results in fewer total crop deaths than an omnivorous diet.

citations.title: the opportunity cost of animal based diets exceeds all food losses

claim: veganism is elitist and not accessible to everyone.
fact: while access to diverse plant-based foods can vary, many staple vegan foods like legumes, grains, and vegetables are widely available and affordable. promoting plant-based diets can be inclusive and adapted to various cultural and socioeconomic contexts.

claim: dairy production is humane and doesn't harm animals.
fact: dairy farming often involves practices like separating calves from mothers shortly after birth and culling male calves. these practices raise ethical concerns about animal welfare in the dairy industry.

claim: veganism alone won't solve environmental issues.
fact: while no single action can address all environmental problems, adopting a plant-based diet is one of the most effective ways individuals can reduce their environmental footprint, including greenhouse gas emissions, land use, and water consumption.

citations.title: reducing food’s environmental impacts through producers and consumers

claim: humans evolved to eat meat, so it's natural and necessary.
fact: the 'appeal to nature' fallacy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appeal_to_nature) suggests that just because something is natural, it is not necessarily good or necessary. while humans are omnivorous and have historically consumed both plant and animal foods, modern nutritional science shows that a well-planned vegan diet can provide all essential nutrients. the 'naturalness' of meat consumption doesn't imply necessity or optimal health.

citations.title: position of the academy of nutrition and dietetics: vegetarian diets

claim: soy increases estrogen levels and is harmful.
fact: soy contains isoflavones, plant-derived compounds that can bind to estrogen receptors but have much weaker effects than human estrogen. studies indicate that moderate soy consumption does not increase estrogen levels in humans and may offer health benefits, such as reducing menopausal symptoms and lowering the risk of certain cancers.

claim: eating local meat is more sustainable than imported plant foods.
fact: transportation contributes a very small fraction to food's total greenhouse gas emissions. the majority comes from production, especially in animal agriculture. plant-based diets generally have a lower environmental impact, even when considering transportation.
